message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is up to date on all vaccines except MMR, which is recommended at 12-15 months of age. Rotavirus vaccine is typically given at 2, 4, and 6 months of age. Meningococcal vaccine is not indicated at this age. A gross motor workup and evaluation is not indicated based on the patient's current development.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is 12 months old and up to date on all vaccines, so the next recommended vaccine is the MMR vaccine. Rotavirus and meningococcal vaccines are recommended at younger ages. A gross motor evaluation may be appropriate at a later checkup, but it is not the most appropriate at this visit.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is up to date on vaccines, but at 12 months, she is due for the MMR vaccine. The other options are not indicated at this time based on the patient's current age and medical history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is up to date on all vaccines and is healthy. The appropriate vaccine for this visit would be the MMR vaccine, as it is recommended for children between 12-15 months of age. Rotavirus vaccine is typically given earlier, at 2, 4, and 6 months of age, and meningococcal vaccine is not typically given until adolescence. Gross motor workup and evaluation may be appropriate at a well-child visit but is not urgent in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only the MMR vaccine is appropriate for the patient’s age and vaccine schedule. Rotavirus vaccine is given to infants between 6 weeks and 8 months of age, and meningococcal vaccine is usually given to adolescents. Gross motor workup and evaluation are not necessary for this routine checkup visit.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is up to date on all vaccines except MMR, so the most appropriate choice for this visit would be to administer the MMR vaccine. The other options are not necessary at this time based on the patient's age, vaccination status, and lack of specific risk factors or symptoms. A gross motor workup and evaluation may be done at a routine checkup but is not urgent or necessary in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is up to date on vaccines but is due for the MMR vaccine at 12-15 months of age. The other options are not indicated at this visit based on the patient’s medical history and age. A gross motor workup and evaluation is recommended at 9 months, not 12 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is up to date on vaccines, but there is no information on whether she has received the MMR vaccine. Given that the mother is concerned about potential exposure to unvaccinated children, the MMR vaccine is the most appropriate choice to ensure protection against measles, mumps, and rubella. The other options are not necessary at this visit. A gross motor workup and evaluation would be appropriate if the toddler was not meeting expected developmental milestones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is up-to-date on vaccines and the given information does not suggest any need for the Rotavirus or Meningococcal vaccine. A gross motor workup is also not necessary based on the information provided. Therefore, the most appropriate option for this patient at this visit would be to administer the MMR vaccine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is up to date on all vaccines except MMR vaccine according to the provided information. MMR vaccine is appropriate for the patient at this visit. Rotavirus vaccine is typically given at 2, 4, and 6 months of age. Meningococcal vaccine is not typically given until 11-12 years of age. Gross motor workup and evaluation may be necessary if there are concerns about developmental milestones, but there is no indication of this from the provided information.
